Same here mostly (including echoing your statement
about it being a little scary to jump into the
discussion).

I'd like to add that in my recent experience on a team
of 4 developers, it's been very hard to convince the
others of the value of the unit tests.  I find they
rarely run the tests that are there, often check in
code that breaks the tests (but not the build), and
they very frequently add new code that's untested.

I'm not sure what to do.  I value the tests, and am
trying to do test-first development, but I'm playing
catch-up with testing the other developer's code, or
more likely letting the coverage suffer.  We use EMMA
for code coverage, but I think I'm the only one who
looks at the reports.

Some parts of the code are not easy to test, and I
sympathize with my coworkers on that account.  I just
got started with easymock to get better coverage for
the hard-to-test bits, but I'm afraid I'll alienate my
non-test-infected coworkers even more by using it.

Anyway, I don't have any answers really, but to answer
the OP's question I am "really using JUnit during
development", but there are certain pains involved. 
On the whole I still think it's worth the effort, but
I do wish the effort required was less.

--- "James P. Gunderson" <gunders@...> wrote:

> Scary to step into the discussion at this point.
> 
> But....
> 
> We test everything we can test. We strive for the
> goal that nothing 
> ships without complete automated tests. As a Java
> shop, we use JUnit.
> 
> However, we do not use testing as a design tool. We
> use a spiral model 
> built around testing and design and coding. Some
> code is written test 
> first, some code is tested after it is written. All
> code is designed 
> into the software structure before it is committed
> to source code. As 
> long as the code is tested before it ships, we are
> confident that it 
> works. But we do not do test first design.
> 
> Jim
>
